text: this week's movies CBGB Romeo and Juliet
and Captain Phillips directed by Paul
Greengrass captain Phillips is about the
real-life takeover of a container ship
by somali pirates in her review Manohla
Dargis writes the film has a vital moral
immediacy and insistently closes the
distance between us and them kinetic
action and intelligence are driving
forces but the carnal excitement that
almost inevitably comes with certain
types of screen violence never manifests
we push the ship to HOD we're off the
grid that means the computers now
offline captain the ship's broken
captain no one gets hurt if you don't
play no game instead it is replaced by
dread anxiety a shaking man and a whole
lot of blood and it's the kind of blood
that most movies void okay
look at me sure look at me sure under
captain now it's a win-win CBGB gets new
customers buying drinks and we get to
play for an audience directed by randall
miller CBGB is a feature film based on
the legendary punk venue in his review
AO scott reitz you have no idea what's
about to happen here because of the
cruel accidents of age and geography I
never set foot in CBGB during its 1970s
punk heyday so I can't say with the
authority of experience it wasn't like
that I will leave it to others to point
out the film's lapses and chronology
taste and historical detail rocks but on
the other hand I would swear on a stack
of dead boy t-shirts that it could not
possibly have been like that so silly so
trivial so boring there is definitely
which nice lad why don't swear at all
and listen hard are we too rash too
unadvised too quick no for this bud of
love and summers breath will prove a
beauteous flower when next we meet
directed by carlo carlei romeo and
juliet is adapted for the screen by
Julian Fellowes in her review Noah
darkest writes passions and nostrils
flare in the latest screen version of
Romeo and Juliet a sufficiently
entertaining adamantly old-fashioned
adaptation that follows the plays
general outline without ever rising to
the passionate intensity of its
star-crossed crazy kids the young pair
are nice to look at but are an awkward
fit no matter how attractively they go
through the chaste motions this is a
noticeably kissy Romeo and Juliet yet
all that nuzzling lee accentuates the
couple's lack of urgency
just buy them madam
